data.title: More Serializers For IntermediateSerializer
data.body: This adds some missing primitive and math types to the IntermediateSerializer along with a tests.

data.title: Implemented IntermediateSerializer.Deserialize
data.body:
This PR implements `IntermediateSerializer.Deserialize<>()` and replaces the implementation of `XmlImporter` with it.  All the unit tests added in #2655 successfully pass.

![tests](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/3566666/f97ae65c-0afd-11e4-894d-ccd4e40dc9ff.PNG)

I fully expect there to be holes in the implementation and cases we're not handling.  Please submit bug reports with specific cases that we're not handling correctly.

Things left to do:
- Some better error reporting with file and line numbers.
- Add `IntermediateSerializer.Serializer<>()` implementation.
- More unit tests.

Fixes https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/2798.

data.title: Fixed volume up/down buttons being handled twice on Android.
data.body:
Volume up/down buttons were changing volume by 2 steps instead of 1 step.
Bug caused by https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/2789.

data.title: GraphicsResource requires GraphicsDeviceManager
data.body:
Do not attempt to access `GraphicsResource` instances without a valid `GraphicsDeviceManager`.

Fixes issue #2805

data.title: [OpenGL] Effect.FlushCache timing
data.body:
I just pushed this change to MG-SDL2:

https://github.com/flibitijibibo/MonoGame/commit/87af9e3d75cced2bcc883ff583ca52d6ec74eb43

Basically, when the cache is flushed after the GraphicsDevices and GamePlatform have all been disposed, the GL context that made the shaders is no longer available, so those GL calls will either produce a silent error or possibly segfault. In the case of OpenTK GL, the entry points from GetProcAddress are still assigned, so it does still call the GL, but it doesn't seem to segfault... somehow. Tools like vogl will catch this, though.

I wasn't sure how the above commit affected other graphics backends, but this could be a possible issue for the OpenGL platforms (particularly the ones with more sensitive drivers). I also don't know if this is the best place to put it, but it does at least get everything before the GL context is gone.

data.title: Moved namespace docs to a single file.
data.body:
As suggested in PR 2802 (https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/2802), moved namespace documentation into its own file. Included this file in the project definition file.

Also, (possibly) unrelated: it looks like the documentation page on the website is currently empty (http://www.monogame.net/documentation/). Not sure if this is related to the previous PRs with documentation changes.

data.title: DirectX Present 30 fps vsync on "power saver" profile
data.body:
EDIT: This is not valid, I was writing this from memory from tests I ran two weeks ago and erroneously reported it as the problem. I'm leaving this here for coherency.

Not sure if this has been discussed before and I can't really find much on google on this topic. If you disconnect from a power source and have the default "power saver" plan enabled on Windows 7, ApplicationIdle fires much much slower (around 30 times a second). 

I found this out by using the latest MoneGame source and timing the actual fire rate on Application Idle event. All of this is fine and makes sense, but what is really counter intuitive is that if you turn off Fixed FPS you go from 60FPS to 30FPS since Fixed FPS calls update multiple times enforcing the 60FPS.

I wanted to put this here in case someone else wonders why they get a huge frame rate drop after turning off Fixed FPS and possibly start a discussion if this is OK by design since I'm not sure how XNA runs it's game loop. While I understand 99% of the games out there are just fine with Fixed FPS on, it drove me nuts knowing that the frame rate was cut in half when disabling it and I had to figure out why.

data.title: Several minor documentation improvements.
data.body:
- Noted in the Documentation\README that SharpDoc is used to generate documentation output files.
- Added namespace documentation for Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.
- Minor typo fix in a comment in MonoGame.Framework/Windows8/XamlGame.cs.

data.title: Fixing path for ContentBuilder project templates
data.body:
Recent changes in MonoGame installation paths on Windows resulted in errors when creating ContentBuilder projects.

MonoGame.ContentPipeline.targets moved from "Program Files (x86)\MonoGame\v3.0" to "Program Files (x86)\MSBuild\MonoGame\v3.0"
MonoGameContentProcessors.dll as well.

I have checked the other templates and everything else seems to be fine.

data.title: Copied Visual Studio 2012 templates and adapted them for Visual Studio 2013
data.body:
As discussed in #2754, this is a copy of the Visual Studio 2012 templates with the version number changed.

This should solve issue #2228.

data.title: Remove BuildProcessTemplates
data.body: This removes old TFS stuff we haven't used in years.  Fixes https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/2792.

data.title: Xml Importer does not seem to accept arrays
data.body:
I've got a XML file:

``` XML
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<XnaContent xmlns:ns="Microsoft.Xna.Framework">
  <Asset Type="BoxIt.TileMapSaveData">
    <Tiles>0 0 0 0 0</Tiles>
  </Asset>
</XnaContent>
```

And a class:

```
namespace BoxIt
{
    public class TileMapSaveData
    {
        public int[] Tiles { get; set; }
    }
}
```

But when I try to put it through the content pipeline I get the following error:

```
error: Importer 'XmlImporter' had unexpected failure!
System.NotImplementedException: Value type arrays are not implemented for type 'Int32'
```

Are arrays not supported or do I have a mistake in my code or XML file?

data.title: Windows Phone 8 and lifecycle management
data.body:
Making the Game.Exit method obsolete causes the game loop to run indefinitely with no way to end it.

While the Microsoft store does not allow exit(), MonoGame needs to provide a way to terminate it's run loop so that the game container can handle the back-button properly. Otherwise, a default back button behavior will leave the game in the "all black screen" mode while it endlessly processes tick() calls.

data.title: Converted an un-readable character to a '
"thru" -> "through"
data.body: Minor typo fix.

data.title: Fixed AndroidRuntimeException: requestFeature() must be called before adding content
data.body:
This exception is raised when Android system recreates activity that uses Fragments.
To fix this, I moved `RequestWindowFeature(WindowFeatures.NoTitle)` before `base.OnCreate (savedInstanceState)`.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16939814/android-util-androidruntimeexception-requestfeature-must-be-called-before-add

data.title: What is BuildProcessTemplates?
data.body:
Anyone know what this is?

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/tree/develop/BuildProcessTemplates

Can we kill this stuff?  Is it in use and critical?

data.title: New MonoGame Logo
data.body:
The team is happy to be introducing the new MonoGame logo:

![horizontallogo_128px 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/3550203/c906f666-08d5-11e4-962d-268015c47c8e.png)

This PR replaces all the old icons, splash screens, installer images, etc.

We also have moved all the MonoGame "branding" in the Graphics folder over to [a new repo](https://github.com/Mono-Game/MonoGame.Logo) specifically for that content.  The idea is to avoid bloating up the main development repo with source art that people rarely need.

The next steps will be updating the branding on the website, Twitter, and Facebook pages.

data.title: Fix Texture2D SaveAs to work on WindowsGL
Fix Android back button behavior
data.body:
Fix handling of KeyUp/Down events so they can still be intercepted by others (and the activity)
Added proper support for the back button (by moving the task to the background)

data.title: Fixed Texture2D.GetData on Windows Phone
data.body: I made a mistake in my last commit with this one. It is now fixed. Tested on Lumia 930 which uses row pitching.

data.title: NullReferenceException when loading a PNG into Texture2D
Android.Media.AudioManager.GetProperty not found exception
Pipeline Does MGCB Search
data.body:
After converting the tools over to use Protobuild, the Pipeline and MGCB executables began building into their own separate folders.  This means that by default Pipeline can't find the location of MBCB when running from the normal build locations.

This PR adds a simple search for the MGCB.exe in a few known locations.  This solves our immediate issue and can be expanded later for Mac, Linux, environment vars, regkeys, etc.

data.title: Adding Tests To Protobuild
data.body:
This PR converts over the test projects to use protobuild.

With this change the tests are now in the same solution as the framework and content pipeline projects.  Hopefully this will encourage people to work more on the tests.

Note the XNA version of the tests were not converted to use Protobuild.  To run them you must manually add the `MonoGame.Tests.XNA.csproj` into the solution.  We'll look to fix this in the future.

data.title: Add support for multisampled rendertargets in most OpenGL platforms
data.body:
Tested on WindowsGL, iOS (iPad mini, air and iPhone 5s) and Android (Nexus5, Nexus7, Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7inch, Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 8inch).

This PR also pave the way for MRT and RenderTargetCube support on those platforms (when available) but I decided to keep this as simple as possible so it can be easily merged.

There are a couple more extensions available to extend support to more Android devices but the ones in this PR are the most common (and robust).

data.title: Content Pipeline Internal Plugin API
data.body:
Currently the content pipeline has to be built to support specific platforms.  For instance the content pipeline has to know how to do DXT and PVRTC compression.  In this case that is ok as these are public formats on open platforms.

The problem comes in when we have to deal with platforms like PlayStation4 or XBox One where there will be closed source formats that cannot be built into the existing content pipeline.

Currently our solution is sort of lame.  We have a "special" build for these platforms that has the private bits needed for close platforms.  This then requires us to have multiple content pipelines installed on the same system and we have to select the right one based on the target platform.  This is a mess.

Instead we should develop a simple API internal to the content pipeline assembly that abstracts these platform details.  For instance if you just consider texture compression:

```
interface ITextureCompressor
{
  void CompressTexture( GraphicsProfile profile,
                       TextureContent content, 
                       ContentProcessorContext context, 
                       bool generateMipmaps, 
                       bool premultipliedAlpha);
}
```

At startup the pipeline would load all the `Pipeline.Plugin.XXXX.dll` found in the pipeline install path.  Then using attributes we would find the correct `ITextureCompressor` for a particular target platform.

This same technique will be used for other cases like sound effect conversion, song conversion, video conversion, etc.

This sort of design allows us to easily extend an existing MonoGame content pipeline install with platform specific formats.

data.title: MediaPlayer.Volume affects all sounds
data.body: It seems like whenever I try to use MediaPlayer.Volume to change the volume of a background song it affects all sounds (sounds playing via SoundEffect). This is on Windows 7 using an unstable build I just downloaded from TeamCity. The stable 3.2 build does this too. My code works fine using XNA.
